descriptor.name: Study description
descriptor.value:
Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified a large number of common variants associated with complex human phenotypes. However in all cases the proportion of the trait variance explained by common variants remains small (less than 5%) suggesting that additional variants contributing to disease and trait heritability have yet to be discovered. One hypothesis is that rarer variants (which are poorly tagged in current GWA arrays) maybe more penetrant than common variants and collectively contribute to a substantial proportion of trait variance. Indeed, such variants, mostly described within exons and affecting protein sequence, have already been found to influence metabolic traits such as lipid levels.
This project is a pilot study focused on re-sequencing the entire exome in DNA samples from 500 individuals with the aim of exploring the technical feasibility of this approach and identifying coding variants that are associated with a propensity to develop metabolic abnormalities (defined primarily through elevated glucose levels/diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus [T2DM]) among overweight and obese individuals. The samples are from an extreme discordant case-control study nested within the clinically well-characterized CoLaus population-based study of around 6,000 participants from Lausanne, Switzerland.

Abstract
descriptor.value:
The 500 exome pilot project is a collaborative exome resequencing experiment using 500 individuals from the CoLaus study based in Lausanne, Switzerland. The collaboration is between the Sanger Institute, GSK and Lausanne University. CoLaus is a population-based study of around 6,000 participants from Lausanne. The case samples for this pilot have been chosen to have a BMI>25 and diabetes or high blood glucose levels, and are 1:1 matched with controls. The controls have low glucose levels and are matched to the cases for BMI (within 1 unit), age (within 7 years) and sex.
Sequence capture will be performed on individual samples using the Agilent Sure Select All Exon Kit based on the CCDS database at NCBI. One lane of 54bp read length PE sequencing will be run on an Illumina GAII to assess the quality of the library before requesting additional lanes on a sample by sample basis if required depending on coverage. Sequence analysis will comprise sequence assembly, sequence mapping to the exome, identification of all variants, mapping variants with respect to exons, noting their likely effect on protein sequence, and capturing the minor allele frequency of each variant identified.
We aim to identify rare genetic variants and eQTLs associated with a propensity to develop metabolic abnormalities among overweight and obese individuals.
